title: New: This Town Needs Guns – Adventure, Stamina & Anger
content:
In a tone befitting the end of an era, I’m going to get all sentimental for a moment.

I can still remember the first time I really listened to This Town Needs Guns. It was probably nearly exactly four years ago. Walking home on a bright, brisk autumn day much like this one, I fished my phone out of my pocket to find a text from a friend, saying simply, ‘Listen to 26 is Dancier than 4 by This Town Needs Guns’. When I got in, I dutifully fired up the computer, pulled up MySpace, and did so.

I think that no sooner had the song’s last notes faded out (maybe for the third or fourth time), I dialled the individual who had set me on this path and unleashed a torrent of unintelligible gibberish down the line, the gist of which was that TTNG’s marriage of barefaced, unapologetic angst to ultra-melodic hypertapping, was, y’know, just my kind of thing. Suddenly a whole bunch of bands with Kinsella influences proudly on sleeves seemed to appear. Some of them were good. Some were bloody awful, and it all got a bit boring in the end. But I heard This Town Needs Guns before I heard the rest of ’em, and I don’t think they ever really got outdone.

Adventure, Stamina & Anger is the swansong of Guns’ frontman and sometime guitarist Stuart Smith, who’s departing on particularly happy terms for the realms of fatherhood. Listening to it alongside oldies like 26… it’s apparent how much more competent the Oxford-based four piece have become. Where I used to pine for the distorted chording that characterised Guns’ split with Cats & Cats & Cats, the mellifluous clusters of notes that populate Adventure wouldn’t make sense in that context, but thoroughly do in this one.

This Town Needs Guns are continuing onward with Henry Tremain (him from Pennines) in place of Smith, and head into the studio to record their second full length next week. You can download Adventure, Stamina & Anger via the Guns bandcamp, or head over to hellomerch to preorder a physical copy. Keep track of goings on in the This Town Needs Guns camp via their website.
